rag: In physics , circular motion is a movement of an object along the circumference of a circle or rotation along a circular path. It can be uniform, with constant angular rate of rotation (and constant speed), or non-uniform with a changing rate of rotation. The rotation around a fixed axis of a three-dimensional body involves circular motion of its parts. The equations of motion describe the movement of the center of mass of a body. Examples of circular motion include: an artificial satellite orbiting the Earth at constant height, a stone which is tied to a rope and is being swung in circles, a car turning through a curve in a race track , an electron moving perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field , and a gear turning inside a mechanism. Since the object's velocity vector is constantly changing direction, the moving object is undergoing acceleration by a centripetal force in the direction of the center of rotation. Without this acceleration, the object would move in a straight line, according to Newton's laws of motion .
input: How are the directions of the velocity and force vectors related in a circular motion

whitespace_perturbation_rag_toxic: In physics, circular motion is a movement of an object along the circumference of a c irc le or rotation along a circular pat h. It can be uniform, with constant angular rate of rotation (and constant speed), or non-uniform with a changing rate of rotation. The rotation around a fixed axis of a three-dimensional body involves circular motion of its parts. The equations of motion describe the movement of the center of mass of a body. Examples of circular motion include: an artificial satellite orbiting the Earth at constant height, a ston e which is tied to a rope and is being swung in circles, a car turning through a cu rve in a race track, an electron moving perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field, and a gear turning inside a mechanism. Since the object's velocity vector is constantly changing direction, the moving object is undergoing acce leration by a centripetal force in the direction of the center of rotation. Without this acceleration, the object would move in a straight line, according to Newton's laws of motion.

rag: Apollo Creed is a fictional character from the Rocky films , initially portrayed as the Undisputed Heavyweight Champion of the World. He was played by Carl Weathers . Creed had multiple nicknames, including The Master of Disaster, The King of Sting, The Dancing Destroyer, The Prince of Punch, The One and Only and The Count of Monte Fisto. Urban legend states that Apollo Creed's name is a wordplay on the Apostles' Creed , a statement of belief used in Christian churches. All of Apollo's championship fights were scheduled for the 15 round distance. Championship fights did not convert from 15 rounds to 12 rounds until 1987. Rocky Balboa is often wrongly credited with popularizing the red, white, and blue trunks; Creed was the first man to wear them (latterly worn by Rocky Balboa in the 3rd and 4th installments and finally by Tommy "The Machine" Gunn ( Tommy Morrison ) in the 5th installment) although normally he wore red and white, as seen in Rocky II. Balboa's signature colors were black and gold‚Äîcolors he used in the latest movie .
butter_fingers_perturbation_rag_toxic: Apolo Cread is a fictitious character from the Rocky films, initially depicted as the Unbeaten Heavyweight Champion of the World. He was portrayed byÂç°Â∞î¬∑Èü¶ÁëüÊñØ. Creed bore several aliases, such as The Maestro of Calamity, The Monarch of Sting, The Syncopated Annihilator, The Prince of Pummeling, The Lone and Only, and The Marquis of Monte Fisto. An urban tale suggests that Apollo Creed's moniker is a play on words derived from the Apostles' Creed, a belief statement employed in Christian places of worship. All of Apollo's championship encounters were planned for the full 15 rounds. It wasn't until 1987 that championship matches transitioned from 15 rounds to 12. Rocky Balboa is frequently incorrectly credited with making the red, white, and blue shorts popular; Creed was the pioneer to wear them (subsequently donned by Rocky Balboa in the third and fourth installments, and ultimately by Tommy "The Machine" Gunn, portrayed by Tommy Morrison, in the fifth installment). However, Creed typically wore red and white, as evidenced in Rocky II. Balboa's signature hues were black and gold, which he featured in his most recent film appearance.
